content: Tried a naive solution and got caught off guard by the performance test, that being said, cool question üëç

That's a nice puzzle! I would just suggest maybe outputting "true" and "false" instead of "YES" and "NO", so that it matches the string value of booleans in most languages. Or was it intentional to force the use of a conditional in shortest code solutions?

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice idea.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: If you figure out the right way to solve it for larger test cases it is easy. Without that it's hard so it's a nice balance. Two validators return YES, two returns NO, so a standard print "YES" or print "NO" gets you only 50%. Nicely balanced.

A few notes:
* (A string without 1 palindrome substring is also a perfect string) <- this is not needed because every non-empty string has palindrome subsatrings (namely the one character substrings).
* The first sentence should be:
  * A string is called a perfect string if all of its palindrome substrings have odd length.
* Input: "s string" Small s not capital so it matches the stub.
* The stub output is usually "YES/NO".
* Output change: Write 'YES' if it is a perfect string, 'NO' if it isn't.
* Constraint: "length(s) <= 10^5". The last test case reaches that.

Let me just say that I loved your solution to this problem. It took me a minute to prove that it always works. So if you address the rephrasing, I'm happy to approve.

I hate true or false because it's the same in MOST languages but not all, so it's an unfair advantage if you are good in those. Yes and No - while sounding very clumsy - is perfect because that's not the value of booleans ever, so you have to hardcode it in the same way in all languages.

That's a fair point.
I'd like to note, though, that code golf is definitely unfair in many ways if you make people compete in different languages. Look at Java and the need for a main class and method, compared to, say, python.

It doesn't mean we shouldn't do the little things that make it a bit more fair, though. So I agree with you on this specific topic.

Absolutely agree with you. Years ago I searched for code golfing in C#. One of the first results was: C# is designed to not do code golf. Then they gave a few tips, but it was a very funny headline.

Another added bonus if you like code golf is that the yes/no answer can teach you concepts like ternary operator. While searching for that you may find concepts like Kotlin's Elvis operator. I believe it can be a good ground for newcomers or those who want to learn new languages.
